title: A Semantic Portal for Next Generation Monitoring Systems

author: Evan W. Patton, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute

segmentation: OK hello everyone, my name is Evan Patton and I'm here to present some work on.
Me to present some work that I did with a number of colleagues.
It evolved out of a class project and so this was work with Jinsang, Ping Wang, Timothy Lee, Bo leading, Qing, Liu, Joanne Luciano, and Deborah McGuinness.
And it is a semantic water quality portal and what it does is it integrates data from different sources and we apply regulation ontologies over those data in order to identify pollution.
So this came out of a real life motivating example.
And the idea was in my hometown there was an issue where children were getting diarrhea.
And people want to know why this was happening and it turned out there was coli in the water, but there are a number of concerns.
The first was, well, you know, when did it happen?
How exactly did it happen?
What could we do to prevent it in the future?
And what we really need is to help develop these informatics systems that can help answer these questions and allow people to make a difference in their community and improve the water.
Body.
Now the number of challenges that come out of this.
The first is that from these different data sources you also get raw data.
You get CSV files or flat ASCII files every once in awhile you get a web service that you can talk to, but that makes it difficult to integrate some of the data.
The other thing is that in a lot of cases there are no semantics in that data.
Usually you have to look up a table or a column in a PDF file to figure out what it means, then use that in order to proceed with your analysis.
So machines have difficulty processing this data automatically.
The other thing is, there's a large amount of data, it's spread spatially.
It's spread overtime, there can be a potentially large number of pollutants, and the analysis of all this information can be complex and time consuming.
So.
So semantics can help in a number of ways.
The first is that we have tools out there that can convert these raw datasets into RDF, and we provide ontologies to help with the integration process.
The second is that using our two data type restrictions and intersections, we can actually represent different things and do pollution recognition on the data.

And Lastly, we've been work doing a little bit of work on using tools like the Sparkle construct query and applying pellets so that we can do automated reasoning over small subsets of the data in order to improve efficiency.
Now originally this started off as a single application focused solely on water, but one things we decide we want to do going forward is split it up.
So we have this semantico ontology which derives mostly from suite Al Time and some of the Geo information, and we use that to describe pollution concepts and lower socio metadata.

Then what we can do is we can combine that with domain specific information such as water, but you could also use it for air and other topics and then using all that, we can use the semantics of L2 to provide simplifying query mechanisms to the system.
So Samantha Aqua is the water specific component of this.
The idea is that identifies water pollution sites.
It pulls data from the United States Geological Survey and the Environmental Protection Agency and converts it into RDF.

The nice thing is that demonstrates how these tools that use semantic web data can actually be used to address some of the challenges that we discussed earlier and really in the long term we want to use this as a tool to help empower citizens and citizen scientists to better explore water related information in their area.
And to hopefully encourage a lot.
Social change.
So here's an overview of the system architecture and basically in the top left corner you have where we're doing our data conversion.
So we pulled down the CSV data files.

We run it through a tool developed in our lab, called CSV to RDF, and that generates RDF data along with Provenance Trace including all of the parameters that went into the tools that you can re run it at a later time and we combine that with regulation ontologies and the two core ontologies.
I'm going to talk about a little bit later to do the reasoning.
So just some statistics on what we've been able to do so far.

We've taken 26 States and this is still ongoing, and from them we've extracted almost 60,000 facilities, half a million water sites, almost 30 million individual measurements, and for total of just over 3 billion triples.
We also have some province data which totals just over 1,000,000 for graph level Providence and we do have the option to add triple level Providence alone.
We're not using it because it doesn't serve much purpose at the current time.
Solve our use case.
So this is the ontology.
It's very simple.
The semantico part is the four yellow boxes there, and there are some blue boxes which represent the water components.
Added to that all the great information is the stuff that we've taken from Sweet and Al time and focus in all of these ontologies in mental illness.
To answer this question, if we want to know what things are playing near me, we could say, well, any water source that has a measurement outside of its allowable ranges polluted.
To do that though, you need to have an actual set of regulations, and so we represent that as an intersection.
If I will two classes, and so here is a value from California which actually states that a water source that has 0.01 milligrams per liter of arsenic is polluted.
Now, one of the nice things about this.
This is that it helps simplify the querying process.
So here my here is what you might have as a traditional sparkle query.
That might answer this question.
You know you have to select all this information and you have to look at the structure of the class and find out all the different parameters that describe it.
And you could potentially optimize this in some ways, but here's a rough idea of how this would work.
Of course, once you turn on L2 reasoning, you can.
Throw out a lot of that and just do.

This only requires accessing through triples were only concerned with polluted sites because of the subclass relationships because of the data type restrictions, the reasoner helps pull all that out for us.
And so the nice thing about this is that it helps hide all the complexities so the developers don't have to write at nearly as complicated queries.

If you were to expose some sort of interface for users to perform the query, you definitely don't want to have them looking at the structure of the data to understand how it works, and overall it helps reduce the need of having really deep knowledge to understand what's going on, because you don't want to have to require all users to obtain that knowledge.
So for Providence, we actually have a few different things.
First, we encode all of the information that we get for provenance using the proof markup language.
We have data source level Providence and I mentioned a little bit of this earlier.
We figure out when we pulled the data down from the particular site, we have the original URLs.
So people want to validate it.
The can we have the process information that we used to generate the RDF from that file and then we can use that to actually help with doing Providence based queries.
Secondly, we have reasoning level Providence.
So because we have these ontologies regarding the regulations and we have all the data, we need to be able to tell users.
OK, well it's under this particular regulation that this item became polluted, but under this other regulation it may.
So the interface here we Gray out the parts that aren't important for the current moment, but we display all the information of sites in this little Google map.
User can click on a site and it pops up this little bubble with a table telling you what the contaminantes.
That was found at that location.
It tells you what the value was when it was measured, where the limit is supposed to be, and when it was measured.
So in some of these cases, these things were measured in 2010 and even in early 2011.
So maybe you as a citizen might be concerned about this.
The other thing we started.
Doing is linking out in trying to find OK. What are the health effects of these things?

And it was one thing to just pull the data down, but can we link to other sources to try to identify what would happen if I'm exposed to this for an extended period of time and so that information gets displayed on the right here?
That work is ongoing.
We present a number of facets on the right hand side, so at the top you can see how we use the data source from the PML to actually determine options for the user to choose.
So if the user is only interested in certain set of data, they can deselect the other items and get that particular data source.
We also have a set of regulations so the user picks a certain ontology essentially that they want to apply, and then the whole system works off of that ontology.

In the bottom right and you can see characteristic and health concern filters and what those allows to do is if you're a user and you have diarrhea and you're thinking that maybe the water was to blame for this, you can come in here.
You hit select, it gives you a list based on the data set and you tell it OK.
I feel like I have diarrhea and I'd like to find polluted things around me that cause diarrhea.
And so the system will do that and it will show only the polluted sites that have contaminants that cause diarrhea.
Last thing that we're starting to do is take the information about the user's location based on the zip code they put in and link out to tell them where can you go.
If you want to tell somebody about this problem and so at the top we put a little link that says in this case you need to go to the EPA in Boston and report this particular situation.
So in addition to the map view, we have the ability to do some time series visualization of the data, which helps the users get a different look at how things are going.
You can pick from a number of facets which is shown on the left.
Some facilities have multiple different permits.

Obviously there are many different characteristics in the water that can be measured, and sometimes there are different types of tests that are applied and those different tests have different limits, and so once you do all that you can get a graph as shown on the right where you see two particular peaks that are violations of the regulation limit.
But most of the time it's underneath.
And another interesting thing you can do which isn't displayed here is see when there are consecutive errors, right?
So maybe you're especially concerned because not only was it detected that there was a problem.
But there was a problem multiple times in a row and nobody fixed it.
So with all the data that we've gathered, there's are some issues, and right now we're facing potentially thousands of instances for counting, and we have to be able to classify all that.
And so applying these regulations can be costly and we really want to be able to do is get it in the long term to be done in a reasonable time frame.

So I took Tompkins County New York and they have 140 sites and about 10,000 measurements across those sites, and the classification for the whole data set for that County takes about 200 seconds, which is a little bit excessive, but what we can do is think about how we want to manage that.
The other issue is that.
We have targets on the screen and imagine getting 140 of those at once as the user right?
You can't be bothered with all the clutter and so there are other things we need to do there.
So what we've decided is we need ways to segment in Page data.
So one way we've done this is first we separated all of the data out into statewide graphs and then we start splitting it on an agency basis.
And then once we've split it all up, we need to somehow combine it again.
So what we do is we have this integration mechanism that we use using SPARQL 1.1 construction query.
And we select.

Some subset of the items, so here we're selecting the first 10 of the sites in this particular County, and then we pull out only the triples that are important to the reasoning step, which means that we're not pulling out our DFS label because RDF's label is not helpful for trying to determine if something is polluted, but we have all the information about what the values are, what the units are, and things.

So the nice thing about this is 1 involves less points to consider per display of the interface and also it's pulling out less triples from our back end Triple Store, which means that we're not using as many resources on the network in order to get the information.
Thirdly, we have fast freezing time.
If you have less points, you need to reason about, then obviously you're gonna have less reason, time.
And Lastly, because we're on the semantic web and we are referencing everything by your eyes, it's very easy for us to go back and start pulling out additional information as part of our work.
So just the results of all this.
First, you know data integration is going to be a big problem in environmental Sciences and semantics.
Really making that much more practical.
And you know, we've shown an example in the semantic web system.
It integrates from two sources right now, but we're looking at state governments in University research programs and things like that to start grabbing more data.
And you know, we're also in the process of linking all of our things to DB Pedia as much as we can.
So some of them are already there.
Some of them still need some work, but you know, we have the brothers say, OK, we measured arsenic, but here's also linked to DB pedia arsenic.
Maybe you can find more information later so we could start pulling in information from Wikipedia also.
2nd.
The query and reasoning system that we have in the fact that supported by smart technologies improves our responsiveness, so it's very easy to change something.
We simply either change the ontology we don't have to go back and rewrite a bunch of rules, and in fact we're extracting all this off of HTML pages.
And what we can do from there is one.
We can also narrow the query that we're applying to reduce the amount of data and then the query itself can be simplified because of the fact that we have all the reasoning in there.
The Providence information that we're capturing helps to use provide transparency and trust, right?
So if you come in and we have a lot of data sources now, we didn't just have to, but you know, we are.
Local community group has gone and decided they want to collect water data.
Maybe you trust them less than you want to EPA, and you don't want to include their data in your analysis because you feel like maybe there might be some bias there.
You can support all that.
So you know we're providing all of this Providence information.
We know where the source is and people can repeat the process if they want.
You can have these.
What if scenarios where user can come in?
And like I said, well I live in Rhode Island but I want to see what would happen if we enacted California State regulations right and they can choose so they have the option.
We're not enforcing them into a particular state, but they have the ability to explore the data bit more.
And Lastly, the user might only be interested in the certain sources that we've talked about and they can use that to control where they.
Queries are executed.
So some future work first.
We're currently in the process of expanding the semantic bus system to support all 50 states.
As I mentioned, we have 26 done, but we still have a few more to go.
And also the regulations with respect to those states.
So right now we just have the data, but we also want the regulations and that takes a bit more work as we have to hunt it down.
It's not in a very easy format like it is with the EPA.
We are also curious about flooding weather information.
So you know if it rains a lot or you get a hurricane, you want to be able to know what things overflowed in the area.
Is this potentially affecting the water quality nearby?
And sometimes the regulations can be different because the authorities recognize the fact that when it floods, stuff is going to go everywhere.
So you know we need to be able to account for these types of things.
3rd we want to be able to have some more robust reasoning over contaminants and their corresponding health effects.
So at the moment.
When we look at the diarrhea example and we know that the fecal core form is a potential candidate for that, we want to know what other types of planets around and can we group these?
Can we make them their own class so it's easier to recognize these types of situations?
And Lastly, we've generalized this to that semantico system I talked about earlier, and so now let's talk about.
OK, well can we go to air quality?
Can we go to soil quality?
Are there other areas outside of just environmental aspects where we can say, OK, you know, having this threshold based system for detecting information would be useful.
And so right now we're in the process of working on the air quality stuff, but there's also soil another.
Aereas so.
First off, Semantico provides a simple foundation for doing all this.
And it's a new system and we are still working on all the kinks.
But it shows that it gives an opportunity for people to explore their water data in their area and use that to hopefully inform people around them of issues with that data.

3rd This system illustrates the benefits of applying these technologies, right so now that we have this process of converting the data from the P in the USGS, we don't have to have someone sitting there doing all the work we could actually be just applying the rules on the fly, and if we had some sort of feed, we could even be emailing people like, oh, you know, we found this data point all of a sudden and you should be careful of it.

So there are a lot of opportunities there and the fact that we have the data integration and the fact that we have the provenance so we can go back and actually look at what was happening and all of the reasoning that's in there means that.
Hopefully we have a more responsive system that users can take advantage of.

And Lastly, the magnitude of all the data that we're getting is forcing us to look at how we're using L2 and the scalability issues that come along with that, and we've offered at least a few ways of improving performance in that.
So I just like to brief, like knowledge, Deborah McGinnis and Joanne Luciano who advised this project.
I'm funded under the National Science Foundation Graduate Research Fellowship and our group has funding from many different sources of you listed here.

So thought I'd like to take any questions we have links here and if you're interested in clobbering us, if you have water data you'd like to see your applied in the system, let us know and we glad to work with.
Thank you.
You collecting the monitoring data, water quality, monitoring data for actual waterways such as rivers and lakes, or for drinking water reservoirs.

Take measurements in estuaries and bays and things like right, OK, and so.

The water supplies would be cut off immediately.

Is it took a few days before there was enough influence from people complaining for them to actually go and do the test because the test was relatively time consuming, but in the long term it took about 2 weeks to resolve the whole situation, which is a relatively long time and people were getting sick, so that must be very unusual because I think most authorities who are responsible for drinking water.
They probably almost have to do daily monitoring.
For drinking water quality and then my last question is about how frequently you accessed monitoring data, because it seems like your.
You are analyzing legacy datasets.
Which are going to be updated all the time.
So how often do you harvest the data from these various sites and update your big RDF triplestore?

So right now it's not that frequently because we get in trouble for it, but we'd really like to encourage in the long run is for people to be able to publish their data more frequently, and potentially even have this as a pushing mechanism so they can push their data to us, or at least inform us that there's new data and we can go on and do all of our processes and do it incrementally rather than have to chug through the whole data set.

the EPA are probably concerned about the sensitivity of the data there.
